WaniKani_Meaning_Mnemonic: The eye radical and eye kanji are the same as each other, so now you know them both.
WaniKani_Meaning_Info: Well... you'll know them both as long as you studied your radicals, young grasshopper. If you didn't, then you're just a young grasshopper who needs to study his/her radicals.
WaniKani_Reading_Mnemonic: Your eyes are important to you, right? Sadly, one of your eyes is missing right now, because a sheep grabbed it and pulled it out, and is now running away from you, yelling his sheep call.... "Mehhhhhh (ã‚)!"
WaniKani_Reading_Info: Of course, feel the pain of your eye being gone... and struggle to get it back. You eventually give up because the sheep is too fast, but then you come up with an idea. What if I call out back to the sheep in its own language? Go ahead and cover one eye and start making "MEHHH" noises to see if you can get the sheep to come back to you and give you your eye. It's up to you whether it works or not, but be sure to feel frustrated by its reaction, or happy by it. Either one works.

humanum_full_description_en:
Inscriptions on inscriptions like human eyes, inscriptions on inscriptions may be erected, and the original meaning is eyes. See " Chen ". The characters of the Warring States Period are inherited from the characters of Shang and Zhou Dynasties, and the heads are generally erected. In addition, the shape of the "ç›®" included in the "Compilation of Ancient Pottery Prose" is inherited by the ancient prose of "Shuowen". "Said Wen": "The eye, the human eye. The pictogram. The boy is also heavy. All the eyes belong to the eye." According to the ancient books handed down, Shun, Yu, Xiang Yu, Wang Mang, etc. all have two pupils in each eye. "Zhongtongzi", but the original meaning of the word "ç›®" has nothing to do with "Zhongtongzi".

The "ç›®" in the oracle bone inscriptions can be used as the original meaning, referring to the eyes, as in "Compilation" 165: "Wang Qiyimu" refers to the king's eye disease. In addition, "ç›®" can also be used as a verb, that is, to watch and watch with the eyes. "Collection" 6195: "Almost (call) the head ğ¢€›fang", that is, the order to detect and wait for the country. The word "ç›®" in oracle bone inscriptions can also be used as the name of a person or a country.

" Mu " in bronze inscription is a word for clan names, such as Mujue and Jijue, the father of Yaomu.

In the handed down ancient books, " mesh " can not only be interpreted as eyes and watch, but also can be used to refer to the mesh of a fishnet, "Han Feizi. Foreign Reserve Says Lower Right": "Those who are good at netting, quote the outline, and don't take one by one, and then get it." From this, the meaning of "message" is extended to detail and main items . "Little Erya. "Guangzhou": "Mu, Yaoye." "The Analects. "Yan Yuan": "Yan Yuan said: "May I ask his eyes.""

The characters of the Warring States Period are inherited from the characters of Shang and Zhou Dynasties, and the heads are generally erected. In addition, the shape of the " ç›®" included in the "Compilation of Ancient Pottery Prose" is inherited by the ancient prose of "Shuowen". "Said Wen": "The eye, the human eye. The pictogram. The boy is also heavy. All the eyes belong to the eye." According to the ancient books handed down, Shun, Yu, Xiang Yu, Wang Mang, etc. all have two pupils in each eye. "Zhongtongzi", but the original meaning of the word " ç›®" has nothing to do with "Zhongtongzi". The " ç›®" in the oracle bone inscriptions can be used as the original meaning, referring to the eyes, as in "Compilation" 165: "Wang Qiyimu" refers to the king's eye disease. In addition, " ç›®" can also be used as a verb, that is, to watch and watch with the eyes. "Collection" 6195: "Almost (call) the head ğ¢€›fang", that is, the order to detect and wait for the country. The word " ç›®" in oracle bone inscriptions can also be used as the name of a person or a country. " Mu" in bronze inscription is a word for clan names, such as Mujue and Jijue, the father of Yaomu. In the handed down ancient books, " mesh" can not only be interpreted as eyes and watch, but also can be used to refer to the mesh of a fishnet, "Han Feizi. Eyes: gaze. Eye-catching. Vividly vivid. Eyes refer to anger (use eyes and complexion to indicate to help others, describe arrogant and arrogant mentality. Also known as "direct to anger").
Look, look: eye language. Eye theory (Yu has no self-knowledge or shallow and narrow opinions).
The place, situation or result you want to achieve: purpose (d?) (also refers to the center of the target).
Sub-items subdivided into major items: items. Gangjumezhang.
Name: Number. Cleverly set up a name.
Title: Table of Contents.
One of the grades used in the biological classification system is below "class" and above "family": there are Anseriformes and Galliformes in the class of birds.
Perforations: Mesh.
Refers to the person headed: the boss.

Radicals: ç›®  (eye)
Meaning Mnemonic
The eye radical and eye kanji are the same as each other, so now you know them both.
Well... you'll know them both as long as you studied your radicals, young grasshopper. If you didn't, then you're just a young grasshopper who needs to study his/her radicals.
Reading Mnemonic
Your eyes are important to you, right? Sadly, one of your eyes is missing right now, because a sheep grabbed it and pulled it out, and is now running away from you, yelling his sheep call.... "Mehhhhhh (ã‚)!"
Of course, feel the pain of your eye being gone... and struggle to get it back. You eventually give up because the sheep is too fast, but then you come up with an idea. What if I call out back to the sheep in its own language? Go ahead and cover one eye and start making "MEHHH" noises to see if you can get the sheep to come back to you and give you your eye. It's up to you whether it works or not, but be sure to feel frustrated by its reaction, or happy by it. Either one works.
